THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Marcus R. Durlach, III,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Sherry T. Durlach and Daniel O. Legare as
Sequestrator,        Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Charleston County
Frances P. Segars-Andrews, Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25823
Heard February 18, 2004- Filed May 17, 
  2004

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
Michael A. Molony and Lea B. Kerrison, both of Young, Clement, 
  Rivers & Tisdale, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Jack D. Cordray, of Cordray Law Firm, of Charleston, 
  and Samuel H. Altman, of Derfner, Altman, & Wilborn, of Charleston, for 
  Respondents.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Marcus R. Durlach, III 
  (Husband) appeals the family court order holding him in civil contempt, sentencing 
  him to serve not more than six months in jail, suspended on payment of $292,953.86.Â  
  We affirm the contempt order but reduce the amount owed to $248,890.26, finding 
  that the family court erred in awarding pre-judgment interest.
Factual/Procedural Background
On March 1, 1996, Husband filed 
  for divorce from Respondent Sherry T. Durlach (Wife). Wife counterclaimed and 
  was granted a divorce on grounds of physical cruelty by order dated April 16, 
  1998.Â  The parties have engaged in legal battles concerning the marital property 
  ever since.
Upon divorce, the marital property was divided 
  equally.Â  Among other things, Wife was awarded King at Market LP (KAM), a business 
  formed during the marriage of which Wife was an original limited partner.Â  KAMâ€™s 
  business purpose is the ownership and management of historic buildings located 
  in the heart of Charlestonâ€™s retail and hospitality district.Â  A retail clothing 
  and accessories business incorporated by Wife three and a half years before 
  the marriage is located in one of the buildings.
According to the April 16, 1998 divorce decree, KAM was to 
  be transferred to Wife effective December 10, 1997, the last day of trial.Â  
  The transfer was to include, â€œall current assets, records, cash, receivables, 
  prepayments, deposits, rents and all other assets,â€ including any management 
  agreements with KAM held by Husband.Â  The decree also provided that â€œ[a]ny arrearage, 
  discrepancy, damage (including damages to or changes in the assets), debt, or 
  other charge on the [KAM] partnership or its assets shall be subject to review 
  by this Court â€¦.â€Â  Finally, the decree specified that â€œthe outstanding loan 
  to Wachovia Bank in the amount of $892,500 is secured by the Husbandâ€™s interest 
  in Parkshoreâ€ and therefore â€œHusband shall also be responsible for that debt.â€
Husband appealed several provisions of the divorce decree. [1] Â  During the time the appeal was pending, Husband 
  and Wife entered into a consent order (the Parkshore 
  [2]  Order) dated October 15, 1998, which was approved by the Charleston 
  County Family Court.Â  The primary purpose of the Parkshore Order was to give 
  Husband the authority to re-finance a piece of marital property â€œto preserve 
  the marital estate.â€Â  In addition, the Parkshore Order provided the following:

a.Â  [Husband] continues to manage [KAM], but makes Wachovia 
  payments separately from his other funds.Â  Only ordinary, normal, reasonable 
  expenses shall be paid from the [KAM] account and all other [KAM] funds shall 
  be kept in the [KAM] account.
 â€¦
c.Â  All issues concerning management, oversight and control 
  of marital property pending resolution of the various appeals shall be in the 
  jurisdiction of the Family Court, with hearing only after meaningful mediation 
  efforts.Â  These issues are designated herein by the parties as local issues.

The Parkshore Order also gave Wife the authority to hire 
  an agent to oversee the KAM accounts and management.Â  Â  
Approximately six months later, Wife contended that Husband 
  had mismanaged KAM affairs.Â  In response to Wifeâ€™s claims, the family court 
  judge appointed a sequestrator (Legare) to manage and control KAM in every respect.Â  
  The appointment was prompted after the court discovered canceled checks drawn 
  on the KAM account for payment of the Wachovia debt, [3]  which directly contradicted the terms of the 
  divorce decree and the Parkshore Order.Â  The judge also found that there was 
  an improper accounting of the KAM funds and â€œenjoined and restrained [Husband] 
  from making any withdrawals or disbursements from the accounts of [KAM].â€Â  Accordingly, 
  in addition to managing KAM, Legare was directed to investigate whether KAM 
  assets had been mismanaged.Â Â Â Â Â Â 
In his investigation, Legare found that Husband diverted 
  funds from KAM totaling $160,100.83.Â  Subsequently, Wife and Legare petitioned 
  the court for a rule to show cause, seeking reimbursement of the funds Husband 
  diverted (plus pre-judgment interest, Legareâ€™s fees, and Legareâ€™s attorneyâ€™s 
  fees), and requesting that Husband be held in contempt for violating court orders.Â  
  Husband filed a return and counterclaimed.
After a hearing on December 6, 2001, the court 
  found Husband in contempt, sentencing him to serve not more than six months 
  in jail, suspended on payment of $292,953.86, which represents the amount of 
  KAM funds diverted, pre-judgment interest, and fees owed to Legare and his attorney.Â  
  Husband raises the following issues on appeal:

  
    Did the family court properly hold Husband in contempt?
    
  
    Did the family court properly order Husband to pay pre-judgment interest?
    
  
    Was Husband denied due process?

Law/Analysis
Standard of Review
When reviewing the factual findings of the family court, 
  this Court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Woodall 
  v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 10, 471 S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996).Â  But if the evidence 
  is in dispute, the appellate court should give the trial judgeâ€™s findings broad 
  deference.Â  Id.
More specifically, this Court should reverse a decision regarding 
  contempt â€œonly if it is without evidentiary support or the trial judge has abused 
  his discretion.â€Â  Stone v. Reddix-Smalls, 295 S.C. 514, 516, 369 S.E.2d 
  840 (1988); see also Henderson v. Henderson, 298 S.C. 190, 197, 379 S.E.2d 
  125, 129 (1989) (â€œA finding of contempt rests within the sound discretion of 
  the trial judge.â€).
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Civil 
  ContemptÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
Husband argues that the family court erred by holding him 
  in contempt.Â  We disagree.
Courts have the inherent power to punish for contempt. In 
  re Brown, 333 S.C. 414, 420, 511 S.E.2d 351, 355 (1998).Â  Willful disobedience 
  of a court order may result in contempt.Â  In re Brown, 333 S.C. at 420, 
  511 S.E.2d at 355.Â  A willful act is one done voluntarily and intentionally, 
  with the specific intent of doing something the law forbids.Â  Id.Â  
Civil contempt must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  
  Poston v. Poston, 331 S.C. 106, 113, 502 S.E.2d 86, 89 (1998) (citation 
  omitted).Â  â€œThe purpose of civil contempt is to â€˜coerce the defendant to do 
  the thing required by the order for the benefit of the complainant.â€™â€ Id. 
  at 111, 502 S.E.2d at 88.
In the present case, the family court judge held Husband 
  in contempt for the following: (1) using KAM funds to make payments on the Wachovia 
  debt in 1998 and 1999 in the amount of $140,040.41; (2) writing checks from 
  KAM funds to his attorney in the amounts of $4069 and $1900; (3) paying the 
  Commissioner of Public Works $148.67 from KAM funds for another, non-KAM property; 
  (4) failing to pay KAM $69,383 in unpaid rent and late charges for Durlach Associates 
  office space; (5) bartering rent with Louisâ€™s Restaurant, providing space at 
  KAM in return for a food-and-beverage credit of $350 per month, owing KAM $9,800; 
  (6) bartering rent at KAM for legal services related to the divorce, owing KAM 
  $11,980; (7) bartering advertising with Charleston Business Journal, owing KAM 
  $7,000; and (8) paying himself commissions from the KAM account in the amount 
  of $15,879.32.Â  
In sum, the judge found that Husband â€œmade repeated payments 
  of the funds of KAM for obligations of his own or obligations of other entities.Â  
  He willfully and knowingly violated the requirements of the orders of this court.â€Â  
  Based on these findings, Husband was ordered to pay $292,953.86, representing 
  the amount of misused KAM funds, pre-judgment interest, and professional fees 
  for Legare and his attorney.
On appeal, Husband does not dispute that he made the payments 
  and agreements delineated in the contempt order.Â  Instead, he contends that 
  his actions did not violate court orders.Â  We disagree.
The following orders and their relevant mandates were effective 
  throughout this litigation:

  
    August 19, 1996 Supplemental Order: â€œBoth parties are enjoined and restrained 
  from in any manner mortgaging, selling, secreting, pledging, encumbering, destroying, 
  damaging, giving away, or in any other manner disposing of any real or personal 
  property marital of the parties, pending the final hearing on the merits.â€
    
  
    September 11, 1997 Ex Parte Restraining Order:Â  â€œ[Husband] or any other 
  entity or institution holding martial property is hereby enjoined and restrained 
  from in any manner mortgaging, selling, secreting, pledging, encumbering, destroying, 
  damaging, giving away, or in any other manner disposing of any real or personal 
  marital property of the parties, pending the final hearing on the merits.â€
    
  
    September 24, 1997 Pre-trial Order:Â  â€œ[P]rior to the initiation of any 
  transaction involving the buying, selling, refinancing or leasing of real property 
  by [Husband] of any of [Husbandâ€™s] entities, the terms of the said transaction 
  shall be fully disclosed to [Wife] and the proposed transaction shall require 
  her consent.â€
    
  
    April 16, 1998 Final Order, Decree of Divorce, and Judgment:Â  â€œBecause 
  the outstanding loan to Wachovia Bank â€¦ is secured by the Husbandâ€™s interest 
  in Parkshore, Husband shall be responsible for that debt.â€Â  The order also transfers 
  KAM to Wife effective December 10, 1997.
    
  
    October 15, 1998 Consent Order as to Parkshore Refinancing:Â  States that 
  â€œ[Husband] continues to manage [KAM] but makes Wachovia payments separately 
  from his other funds.â€Â Â 

First, Husband violated the divorce decree and the Parkshore 
  Order when he used KAM funds to make payments on the Wachovia debt in 1998 and 
  1999.Â  The April 16, 1998 divorce decree specifically stated that Husband was 
  personally responsible for the Wachovia debt.Â  This responsibility was reiterated 
  in the October 15, 1998 Parkshore Order.Â  Therefore, payment of the Wachovia 
  debt with KAM funds violated both the divorce decree and the Parkshore Order.Â Â Â Â  

Second, Husband violated court orders when he bartered free 
  rental space at KAM properties in exchange for food-and beverage credits, legal 
  services, and advertising services.Â  Such activity benefited Husband alone and 
  diminished the value of KAM.Â  Agreements entered into before the divorce decree 
  violated pre-trial restraining orders, and those entered into afterward violated 
  the divorce decree itself.Â Â Â Â  
Third, Husband violated the divorce decree when he paid himself 
  commissions from KAM funds between May 1998 and February 1999.Â  The divorce 
  decree terminated all management and leasing agreements held by Husband and 
  transferred those agreements, and commissions associated with those agreements, 
  to Wife.Â  In addition, Husband violated the divorce decree when he used KAM 
  funds to pay his own legal fees.Â  The receipt of commissions and the payment 
  of legal fees from KAM funds violated the divorce decree.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Fourth, Husband violated pre-trial restraining orders and 
  the divorce decree when he failed to pay overdue rent to KAM on office space 
  for Durlach Associates.Â  Delinquency prior to the date KAM was transferred to 
  Wife diminished the value of KAM in direct violation of the pre-trial restraining 
  orders.Â  Delinquency after the date KAM was transferred to Wife violated the 
  divorce decree itself.
Again, Husband does not deny that he engaged in the activity 
  outlined above.Â  He contends, instead, that he did not violate court orders 
  by managing KAM as he did.Â  Nonetheless, Husband would, at times, reimburse 
  KAM when he discovered that he â€œinadvertentlyâ€ drew from KAM funds.Â  We find 
  that these reimbursements signified Husbandâ€™s awareness that his conduct was 
  contrary to court orders.Â  By willfully disobeying court orders on multiple 
  occasions, Husband provided the family court with clear and convincing evidence 
  upon which to base its decision.Â  Accordingly, we hold that Husband was properly 
  held in contempt.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
In addition to challenging the family courtâ€™s findings regarding 
  the misuse of KAM funds, Husband raises various challenges concerning other 
  findings in the order and events leading up to its issuance.Â  First, Husband 
  argues that the family court judge erred in requiring him to pay a majority 
  of Legareâ€™s and Legareâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Although the June 8, 1999 order for 
  sequestration provided that Legare would be paid by KAM, we believe that this 
  provision did not anticipate the extent of Husbandâ€™s inappropriate use of funds 
  and Husbandâ€™s failure to cooperate with Legare.Â  Therefore, we find that it 
  was within the judgeâ€™s discretionary authority to order Husband to pay a majority 
  of the fees.Â Â Â  
Second, Husband argues that the family court judge should 
  have permitted the parties to mediate their dispute before proceeding with a 
  hearing.Â  We find that it was within the judgeâ€™s discretion to conduct a hearing 
  concerning Legareâ€™s report (and subsequently issue the contempt order) without 
  first requiring that the parties engage in mediation.Â  The Parkshore Order provisions 
  concerning mediation applied during the period pending the appeal, which ended 
  November 8, 2000, one year before the hearing took place.Â  Consequently, it 
  was within the judgeâ€™s discretion to proceed with the hearing accordingly.
Third, Husband argues that his management activities at KAM 
  before Legare was appointed as sequestrator should be deemed â€œvalidâ€ since the 
  original sequestrator did not object or otherwise contest Husbandâ€™s activities 
  during that time.Â  We disagree.Â  The original sequestratorâ€™s lack of objection 
  does not necessarily mean that Husband managed KAM in accordance with court 
  orders.Â  In addition, we find that (1) there is no evidence that the original 
  sequestrator even conducted an investigation, and (2) Legare replaced the original 
  sequestrator and became the sequestrator for all purposes, including for purposes 
  of investigating questions of mismanagement of assets.Â  
Fourth, Husband argues that Legare should not have considered 
  transactions occurring before December 10, 1997, the date KAM was effectively 
  transferred to Wife.Â  We disagree.Â  In his investigation, Legare reviewed activity 
  dating as far back as September 1997, the date of the ex parte restraining order 
  issued against Husband, which was appropriate given that this order controlled 
  Husbandâ€™s activities.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the family court 
  properly held Husband in contempt.
  II.              
Award of Pre-Judgment Interest 
   
Husband argues that the family court erred by ordering him 
  to pay pre-judgment interest.Â  We agree.
Parties must plead for pre-judgment interest in order for 
  it to be recovered.Â  Calhoun v. Calhoun, 339 S.C. 96, 103, 529 S.E.2d 
  14, 17 (2000).Â  When such a plea is made, pre-judgment interest may be recovered 
  â€œon obligations to pay money from the time when, either by agreement of the 
  parties or operation of law, the payment is demandable, if the sum is certain 
  or capable of being reduced to certainty.â€Â  Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 
  355 S.C. 361, 375, 585 S.E.2d 292, 299 (2003); see also S.C. Code Ann. 
  Â§ 34-31-20(A) (2003) (authorizing pre-judgment interest at a rate of 8.75 percent 
  per year â€œin all cases wherein any sum or sums of money shall be ascertained 
  and dueâ€). 
In the present case, we find that Wife and Legare pled for 
  pre-judgment interest in their petition in support of rule to show cause.Â  Additionally, 
  the court, relying on Legareâ€™s comprehensive report, was able to arrive at a 
  sum certain that was due KAM.Â  The sum certain represented the amount of money 
  Husband had used in violation of pre-trial restraining orders, the divorce decree, 
  and the Parkshore Order.Â Â Â  
But because the money due under the contempt order was not 
  part of the judgment in this case, we hold that Wife and Legare are not entitled 
  to pre-judgment interest.Â  The divorce decree represents the judgment in this 
  case, and there is no allegation that money due under the decree was not paid 
  or divided as ordered or agreed to by the parties.Â  The contempt order was issued 
  not because Husband failed to abide by the distribution of funds and property 
  in accordance with the divorce decree but because Husband misused funds 
  in violation of various court orders, including the decree itself.Â  
The purpose of the contempt order was to coerce Husband to 
  reimburse money spent in a manner not approved by the court.Â  As a coercive 
  device, the contempt order is more like a citation than a judgment.Â  Consequently, 
  the sums due under the contempt order are not subject to interest as are money 
  judgments.Â  For these reasons, Wife and Legare are not entitled to pre-judgment 
  interest on money due under the contempt order.
  III.          
Due 
  Process  
Finally, Husband argues that he was denied due process because 
  the family court did not conduct a â€œseparate and distinctâ€ hearing to â€œcertifyâ€ 
  Legareâ€™s report.Â  Further, Husband contends he was denied notice of the sequestratorâ€™s 
  claims and the opportunity to object.Â  We disagree.
â€œA due process claim raised for the first time on appeal 
  is not preserved.â€Â  Bakala v. Bakala, 352 S.C. 612, 625, 576 S.E.2d 156, 
  163 (2003).
Husbandâ€™s due process claim was not raised in the family 
  court and is raised for the first time here.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved 
  for review.
Conclusion
Based on the foregoing analysis, we affirm the 
  family court order finding Husband in contempt.Â  But we modify the contempt 
  order in one respect:Â  Husband is not required to pay $44,063.60 in pre-judgment 
  interest. Therefore, Husband owes KAM $248,890.26, representing the amount of 
  funds diverted from KAM and fees for Legare and his attorney.
 MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice 
  J. C. Nicholson, Jr., concur.

 
   
    [1]  In an unpublished opinion, the Court of Appeals affirmed the divorce 
    decree in all material respects.

 
   
     
    [2] Parkshore Centre I L.P. (Parkshore) was a business formed by Husband for 
    the purpose of acquiring and developing property.Â  Husbandâ€™s partnership interest 
    in Parkshore was deemed marital property for purposes of equitable distribution.Â  
  

 
   
    [3]  The Wachovia loan was primarily secured by Husbandâ€™s interest in 
    Parkshore.Â  The court found that Husband was responsible for paying this debt.Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Anand B. Patel,       
Appellant-Respondent
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Nalini Raja Patel,       
Respondent-Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dillon County
James A. Spruill, III, Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25824
Heard February 19, 2004 - Filed May 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED AS MIDIFIED


  
    
      
John O. McDougall, Peter George Currence, and Emma I. Bryson, of McDougall 
  & Self, of Sumter, for Appellant-Respondent.
Harvey L. Golden and J. Michael Taylor, of Golden, Taylor, Potterfield & 
  Barron, of Columbia, for Respondent-Appellant.
Richard Giles Whiting, of Columbia, Guardian ad
Litem.
      
    
  

 ACTING JUSTICE MACAULAY:  This is a domestic relations case.Â  Both parties appeal.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
This domestic relations dispute 
  has continued for more than eight years without resolution.Â  Anand B. Patel 
  (Husband) and Nalini Raja Patel (Wife) were married on July 7, 1980.Â  Three 
  children were born of the marriage.Â  The partiesâ€™ oldest son, is seventeen. 
  Â The partiesâ€™ only daughter, is thirteen.Â  The partiesâ€™ youngest son, is eleven. 

 Husband sued Wife for divorce 
  in December 1995.Â  On October 23, 1997, the family court issued the final divorce 
  decree.Â  The family court ruled that neither party was entitled to alimony, 
  awarded custody of the children to Husband, split the marital estate 65 percent/35 
  percent in favor of Husband, and awarded Husband $41,920.94 in attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  

In June 1998, Husband informed 
  Wife by letter that he was relocating with the children to Southern California.Â  
  The court denied Wifeâ€™s request for a restraining order prohibiting the move.Â  
  The appeal of the relocation order was consolidated with the appeal from the 
  divorce decree.
In October 2000, the Court of 
  Appeals issued a unanimous, unpublished opinion, in which it (1) reversed the 
  family courtâ€™s award of custody and ordered Husband to return the children to 
  South Carolina, (2) reversed and remanded the denial of alimony to Wife, and 
  (3) reversed the award of attorneyâ€™s fees to Husband, but affirmed the 65/35 
  property division in favor of Husband.Â  Patel v. Patel, Op. No. 2000-UP-653 
  (S.C. Ct. App. dated Oct. 26, 2000).Â  In January 2001, this Court granted Husbandâ€™s 
  petition for an emergency supersedeas to stay the return of the children to 
  South Carolina.Â  
This Court denied Wifeâ€™s petition 
  for a writ of certiorari on the property division issue, and granted Husbandâ€™s 
  petition on the alimony and custody matters.Â  The Court issued an opinion remanding 
  the issues to the trial court for a new hearing on the custody and alimony issues.Â  
  Patel v. Patel, 347 S.C. 281, 555 S.E.2d 386 (2001).
While the remand trial was pending, 
  Wife filed a motion for pendente lite alimony.Â  The family court awarded Wife 
  $2,500.00 per month in pendente lite alimony.Â  The issue of retroactive alimony 
  was reserved for the final trial on remand. 
The final 
  merits hearing on the remanded issues of alimony, child custody, and child support 
  was held over seven days in October and December 2002.Â  The trial court held 
  Wife was entitled to permanent periodic alimony of $1,500.00 per month beginning 
  February 1, 2003.Â  The court did not address the issue of retroactive alimony.Â  
  The trial court awarded custody of the oldest child to Husband and awarded custody 
  of the two younger children to Wife.Â  The order required Husband to pay $1,150.00 
  per month in child support and denied either party attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â Â  

Both Husband and Wife appeal.Â  
  On February 18, 2003, this Court assumed jurisdiction pursuant to Rule 204(b), 
  SCACR.
ISSUES

  
    Did the family court properly deny Husbandâ€™s motion to
    recuse?
    
  
    Did the family court abuse its discretion in awarding custody of the two younger 
  children to Wife?
    
  
    Did the family court abuse its discretion in awarding alimony to Wife, denying 
  Wife retroactive alimony, and setting the amount of alimony at $1,500.00 per 
  month?
    
  
    Did the family court abuse its discretion in setting the amount of child support 
  and denying Wife transportation expenses?
    
  
    Did the family court abuse its discretion in denying Wife attorneyâ€™s fees and 
  litigation expenses?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Where a family court order is 
  appealed, we have jurisdiction to find facts based on our own view of the preponderance 
  of the evidence.Â  The Court is not required to disregard the findings of the 
  trial judge who saw and heard the witnesses and was in a better position to 
  evaluate their credibility.Â  Strout v. Strout, 284 S.C. 429, 327 S.E.2d 
  74 (1985).Â Â  Our broad scope of review does not relieve the appealing party 
  of the burden of showing that the family court committed error.Â  Skinner 
  v. King, 272 S.C. 520, 252 S.E.2d 891 (1979).
I.Â  Recusal
The underlying circumstances supporting Husbandâ€™s 
  motion to recuse arose after we remanded the case to the family court for a 
  new hearing on custody and alimony.Â  In August 2002, Wife contacted three State 
  Senators, asking for their help in having a trial date set for the remand trial. 
  [1] Â  All of these senators wrote letters on behalf of Wife to The Honorable 
  James A. Spruill III, the family court judge presiding over the matter.  [2] Â Â  Two of the senators sent copies of their 
  letters to Chief Justice Toal.  
Judge Spruill 
  wrote the three senators advising them that he was not permitted to consider 
  these communications and immediately set a trial date for October 14, 2002.Â  
  Husband filed a Motion to Recuse and requested a continuance.Â  Judge Spruill 
  denied both motions.Â  Husband then filed suit in federal court against Judge 
  Spruill and the three senators alleging a violation of due process.Â  The pleadings 
  were served on Judge Spruill prior to the merits hearing.Â  The final hearing 
  on the merits began on October 14 and Husband renewed his motion for continuance 
  and recusal, both of which Judge Spruill denied.Â  
Husband asks 
  this Court to acknowledge the appearance of impropriety with the activities 
  of the three senators, and their alleged attempts to sway the opinions of Judge 
  Spruill and Chief Justice Toal.Â  Husband does not wish for the case to be remanded 
  on the custody issue based on Judge Spruillâ€™s failure to disqualify himself.Â Â  
  On the issue of alimony, Husband requests this Court deny alimony because he 
  was denied a hearing before an impartial tribunal.Â  We conclude Judge Spruill 
  was not required to disqualify himself.Â  Accordingly, Husband was not denied 
  an impartial tribunal based on Judge Spruillâ€™s failure to disqualify himself.
 Under South Carolina law, if there is 
  no evidence of judicial prejudice, a judgeâ€™s failure to disqualify himself will 
  not be reversed on appeal.Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc., 332 S.C. 75, 
  504 S.E.2d 311 (1998).Â  In Roche, the Court applied Canon 3(E)(1)(a) 
  of Rule 501, SCACR.Â  Under Canon 3(E)(1)(a), a judge should disqualify himself 
  in a proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned, including 
  but not limited to, instances where he has a personal bias or prejudice against 
  a party.Â  It is not sufficient for a party seeking disqualification to simply 
  allege bias; the party must show some evidence of bias or prejudice.Â  Mallet 
  v. Mallet, 323 S.C. 141, 473 S.E.2d 804 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  If there is no 
  evidence of judicial bias or prejudice, a judgeâ€™s failure to disqualify himself 
  will not be reversed on appeal.Â  Ellis v. Procter & Gamble Dist. Co., 
  315 S.C. 283, 433 S.E.2d 856 (1993).Â  
A judgeâ€™s impartiality might reasonably 
  be questioned when his factual findings are not supported by the record.Â  Ellis, 
  315 S.C. at 285, 433 S.E.2d at 857.Â  There is no evidence in the record suggesting 
  that Judge Spruill was prejudiced by the senatorsâ€™ letters.Â  Judge Spruill acted 
  promptly to alleviate any perception of injustice.Â  Shortly after receiving 
  the letters, Judge Spruill wrote the senators advising them that he is not permitted 
  to consider communications from outside the court.Â  Judge Spruill sent copies 
  of these letters to both partiesâ€™ attorneys.Â  In his January 2, 2003 order, 
  Judge Spruill chastised Wife for her â€œinappropriate attemptâ€ to influence the 
  court by her contact with the legislators.Â  Because there is no evidence in 
  the record supporting Husbandâ€™s contention, we conclude Judge Spruill did not 
  err in failing to disqualify himself.
We granted Husbandâ€™s motion to argue 
  against precedent on the issue of judicial recusal.Â Â  Husband urges this court 
  to adopt the standard for judicial recusal set forth in Liljeberg v. Health 
  Services Acquisition Corp., 486 U.S. 847, 108 S.Ct. 2194, 100 L.Ed.2d 855 
  (1988).Â  Additionally, Husband argues that this Court should adopt a de novo 
  standard of review on the recusal issue.Â  In Liljeberg, the United States 
  Supreme Court considered the construction of 28 U.S.C. Â§ 455(a) (2001).Â  The 
  federal statute is similar to Canon 3(E)(1)(a).Â  Section 455(a) provides, â€œ[a]ny 
  justice, judge, or magistrate of the United States shall disqualify himself 
  in any proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned.â€ 

 The issue before the Supreme Court was 
  whether Section 455(a) could be violated based on the appearance of partiality.Â  
  The Court held that under Section 455(a), recusal is required even when there 
  is no evidence of bias if a reasonable person, knowing all the circumstances, 
  would expect that the judge is biased.Â  Liljeberg, 486 U.S. at 860-61, 
  108 S.Ct. at 2203, 100 L.Ed.2d 855 at 872-73.Â  Husband argues that the Supreme 
  Courtâ€™s holding imputes an objective test in applying Section 455(a), in that 
  it does not require evidence of judicial prejudice to warrant disqualification.Â  

We have carefully considered Husbandâ€™s 
  arguments.Â  Assuming without deciding that there is merit in Husbandâ€™s policy 
  arguments supporting the federal rule and de novo standard of review, we decline 
  to adopt these standards at this time because Husband has not demonstrated that 
  he would prevail under the Liljeberg test under these facts even if reviewed 
  de novo.Â  There is no evidence in the record leading an objective observer to 
  question Judge Spruillâ€™s impartiality after he received the senatorsâ€™ letters.Â  
  The letters would not have caused an objective mind, viewing all the facts of 
  the case, to determine Judge Spruill was biased.Â  Disqualification issues are 
  necessarily decided on the facts of each case.Â  In some cases, contact by legislators 
  with members of the judiciary may warrant disqualification.Â  However, to hold 
  that disqualification was mandated under the facts of this case, would require 
  every judge to recuse himself upon receiving unsolicited contact from the legislature, 
  or other potentially influential persons/ organizations, or even officious intermeddlers.Â  
  Such a holding could invite the less scrupulous to employ this stratagem to 
  eliminate any judge.Â  Therefore, we conclude Husband has failed to show Judge 
  Spruill erred in failing to disqualify himself. 
II.Â  Custody
In a custody dispute, the 
  paramount and controlling factor is the welfare and best interests of the child.Â  
  Matthews v. Matthews, 273 S.C. 130, 132, 254 S.E.2d 801, 802 (1979).
 The family court concluded the 
  older son should remain in California with Husband to complete the remainder 
  of his junior year and the entirety of his senior year in high school and that 
  the two younger children should return to South Carolina to live with Wife.Â  

 On appeal Husband argues the 
  family court erred in granting custody of the two younger children to Wife because 
  (1) the court expressed reservations about Wifeâ€™s fitness, (2) Dillon schools 
  were adequate only if the children attended in-state colleges, and (3) daughterâ€™s 
  preference for living with Wife was given controlling weight in awarding her 
  custody of daughter and younger son.Â  
The family court expressed reservations 
  about Wifeâ€™s many episodes of uncontrollable anger that took place within the 
  presence of the children.Â  The court found that Wifeâ€™s anger management problems 
  were ameliorated because the anger was directed toward Husband, not the children.Â  
  Wifeâ€™s conduct is clearly unacceptable.Â  The recorded telephone calls between 
  Husband and Wife reveal the extent of her anger and use of profanity.
Husbandâ€™s fitness as a parent 
  is also problematic.Â  Dr. Boland, a clinical psychologist, testified Husband 
  has exhibited signs of histrionic personality disorder.Â  One characteristic 
  associated with the disorder is a tendency to over-react to minor events and 
  display abrupt outbursts of sarcasm.Â  A former employee of the Days Inn in Dillon 
  testified Husband would scream at Wife when she called.Â  Additionally, Wifeâ€™s 
  calls to the children had to go through Husband first.Â  
Husband has engaged in additional 
  acts of manipulative behavior.Â  While the children were in California, Husband 
  did not make any effort to keep Wife informed about their childrenâ€™s health.Â  
  He did not inform Wife that older son was diagnosed with Attention Deficit Disorder 
  and had been treated for depression.Â  Husband did not inform Wife that both 
  sons were seeing a psychiatrist.Â  
Both parents have exhibited 
  far less than exemplary behavior.Â  In determining custody, the trial court weighed 
  heavily the fact that Wife had been the primary caretaker before the separation.Â  
  Although there is no rule of law requiring custody be awarded to the primary 
  caretaker, there is an assumption that custody will be awarded to the primary 
  caretaker.Â  Roy T. Stuckey, Marital Litigation in South Carolina, 433 
  (3d ed. 2001).Â  In the present case, the court found that Husband devoted long 
  hours to his work, but remained active in the lives of the children.Â  A breadwinnerâ€™s 
  work habits are relevant to custody decisions when considered in the context 
  of the time spent with the children.Â  See Paris v. Paris, 319 
  S.C. 308, 311, 460 S.E.2d 571, 573 (1995) (awarding custody to the primary caretaker 
  over the primary breadwinner).Â  In the present case, Wife saw to the childrenâ€™s 
  day-to-day needs, prepared their meals, took them to school, and saw that the 
  children attended school related activities and religious functions.Â  
Under the facts of this case, we find 
  that the family court did not abuse its discretion in concluding that Wife is 
  a fit parent, despite the courtâ€™s concerns.Â  Moreover, the court did not abuse 
  its discretion in weighing heavily the fact that Wife was the childrenâ€™s primary 
  caretaker.Â  
Second, Husband 
  contends the trial court gave insufficient weight to the superiority of the 
  schools in California in making the custody decision.Â  The family court stated 
  that the schools in Dillon are sufficient to provide the children with the tools 
  to succeed in the colleges within South Carolina.Â  Husband relies primarily 
  on PPSE (Pupil Performance Scholarship Exams) scores in evaluating the schools.Â  
  We conclude that the best interests of the children are not compromised by attending 
  the Dillon, South Carolina schools.Â  The Dillon schools do not directly and 
  adversely affect the best interests of the children, despite the fact that the 
  California schools have higher PPSE scores.Â  Therefore, we decline to modify 
  the custody award simply because one form of schooling is commonly considered 
  superior to another when both schools are adequate.
Third, Husband argues daughterâ€™s preference 
  for living with Wife was given controlling weight in the family courtâ€™s custody 
  decision.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1515 (Supp. 2003) provides:

In determining the best interest of a 
  child, the court must consider the childâ€™s reasonable preference 
  for custody.Â  The court shall place weight upon the preference based 
  on the childâ€™s age, experience, maturity, judgment, and ability to express
preference.Â  

The leading case is Guinan 
  v. Guinan, 254 S.C. 554, 176 S.E.2d 173 (1970).Â  In Guinan, the Court 
  gave â€œgreat weightâ€ to the wishes of a sixteen year old.Â  In this case, daughter, 
  who is now thirteen years old, has consistently expressed a definite desire 
  to live with Wife.Â  The younger son, who is now eleven years old, did not seem 
  to have as definite a preference, although he expressed some interest in staying 
  in California. [3] Â  
We hold that the family court 
  did not abuse its discretion in awarding custody of the two younger children 
  to Wife.Â  Several witnesses testified that the two younger children were happy 
  in Dillon when they visited their mother.Â  A teacher at Dillon Christian School 
  testified that her daughter and the partiesâ€™ daughter have maintained a friendship 
  and that daughter has other friends in Dillon.Â  Another parent with children 
  enrolled at the school testified that the partiesâ€™ daughter visited his daughter 
  in Dillon and has maintained friendships with other students.Â  Both parties 
  agree that the two younger children should not be separated.Â  We agree.Â  Although 
  the legislature gives family court judges the authority â€œto order joint or divided 
  custody where the court finds it is in the best interests of the child,â€ S.C. 
  Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(42) (Supp. 2003), joint or divided custody should only 
  be awarded where there are exceptional circumstances.Â  Under the facts of this 
  case, we hold the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in awarding custody 
  of the two younger children to Wife. 
III.Â  Alimony
The amount of alimony is within 
  the trial courtâ€™s sound discretion and should not be disturbed on appeal unless 
  an abuse of discretion is shown.Â  Smith v. Smith, 264 S.C. 624, 627-28, 
  216 S.E.2d 541, 543 (1975).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs either when a court 
  is controlled by some error of law, or where the order is based upon findings 
  of fact lacking evidentiary support.Â  Townsend v. Townsend, 356 S.C. 
  70, 587 S.E.2d 118 (Ct. App. 2003).
The trial court awarded Wife 
  $1,500.00 per month in permanent, periodic alimony.Â  Husband appeals the award 
  of any alimony.Â  Wife appeals the amount of the award and the trial courtâ€™s 
  denial of retroactive alimony.
Husband argues any award of 
  alimony in this case discourages Wife from procuring employment. See 
  Brandi v. Brandi, 302 S.C. 353, 358, 396 S.E.2d 124, 127 (Ct. App. 1990) 
  (trial judge abused his discretion in the award of alimony because Wifeâ€™s expenses 
  appear excessive when considered in conjunction with the fact that she has not 
  procured employment since her separation).Â  We disagree and affirm the award 
  and amount of permanent, periodic alimony.
The 
  family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding Wife alimony.Â Â  Three 
  important factors in awarding periodic alimony are (1) the duration of the marriage; 
  (2) the overall financial situation of the parties, especially the ability of 
  the supporting spouse to pay; and (3) whether either spouse was more at fault 
  than the other.Â  The fact that this was a long marriage of seventeen years weighs 
  in favor of alimony.Â  Second, Husband has the ability to pay the alimony award.Â  
  The trial court found that both parties have substantial property from the division 
  of the estate. Third, Husband is highly educated, having degrees in biochemistry 
  and pharmacy.Â  Husband currently manages a successful motel business.Â  Wife 
  has a high school education and has been out of the work force for more than 
  twenty years.
Wife 
  contends the $1,500.00 per month alimony award is insufficient.Â  The trial court 
  gave considerable weight to Wife not seeking any employment in the five years 
  since the divorce.Â  Wife testified she has not sought employment for the last 
  five years because her efforts on this case have required her full attention.Â  
  Wife has engaged in what she considers â€œcommunity serviceâ€ work in the Indian 
  community.Â  Wife writes and sells articles for the India Post 
  newspaper.Â  In working for the paper, Wife attends various conferences throughout 
  the country and is â€œreimbursedâ€ from the sponsoring organizations.Â  
We conclude the family court did not abuse 
  its discretion in awarding Wife $1,500.00 per month in permanent, periodic alimony.Â  
  The family courtâ€™s findings are consistent with an application of the factors 
  set forth in South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2003). 
  [4] Â  The family court noted the extended length of the marriage, Husbandâ€™s 
  superior educational background, and the employment history of the parties.Â  
  Wife, thirty-six years old at the time of the divorce, has a twelfth-grade education.Â  
  During the marriage she worked in both family businesses instead of seeking 
  salaried employment.Â  While an award of alimony is appropriate in this case, 
  we agree that any increase in the permanent, periodic alimony would act as a 
  disincentive to Wife in pursuing employment.Â  Accordingly, we find no error.
Wife 
  argues the Court should award her retroactive alimony.Â  We agree, albeit, not 
  in the amount Wife requests.Â  Wife asks this Court to award her $152,500.00 
  in unpaid alimony plus judgment interest. 
  [5] Â  This Court has not specifically addressed whether a party is entitled 
  to retroactive alimony when an appellate court remands for reconsideration of 
  alimony (but does not award alimony on appeal) and the family court then awards 
  alimony.Â  In Green v. Green, 320 S.C. 347, 465 S.E.2d 130 (Ct. App. 1995), 
  the Court of Appeals concluded that under these circumstances a family court 
  may award alimony retroactive to the date of the original hearing unless it 
  would be an abuse of discretion.Â  
Under 
  our view of the facts, Wife should be awarded alimony for all months she was 
  not paid since the date of the original hearing at a rate of $1,500.00.Â  Therefore, 
  Wife should be awarded $1,500.00 per month in retroactive alimony for the sixty-one 
  months she requests. Husband owes Wife $91,500.00 plus interest at a rate of 
  fourteen percent per annum. [6] Â  
  Interest is due on alimony at the time each support payment becomes due.Â  See 
  Thornton v. Thornton, 328 S.C. 96, 114, 492 S.E.2d 86, 96 (1997).Â  Accordingly, 
  Wifeâ€™s post-judgment interest on the alimony arrearage should be calculated 
  from the date each payment was due. 
IV.Â  Child Support
Child 
  support awards are addressed to the sound discretion of the family court and 
  absent abuse of discretion will not be disturbed on appeal.Â  Townsend, 
  supra.Â  Wife appeals the trial judgeâ€™s award of $1,150.00 in child support 
  per month.
Wife argues the 
  family court improperly imputed $900.00 per month in minimum wage to her and 
  improperly imputed $1,958.00 per month of interest on her income.Â  Wife contends 
  that even if the trial judge properly imputed income to her, the award of $1,150.00 
  deviates from the South Carolina Department of Social Services Guidelines formula.
We hold the family 
  court properly imputed income to Wife.Â Â  It is proper to impute income to a 
  party who is voluntarily unemployed or underemployed.Â  Mazzone v. Miles, 
  341 S.C. 203, 532 S.E.3d 890 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Wife testified that she has not 
  sought employment because her full-time job is â€œto get custody of [her] children.â€Â  
  Wife also indicated that she has no intention of seeking employment if she acquires 
  custody of the children.Â  Although Wife has been out of the work force for more 
  than twenty years, the family court found she is capable and energetic.Â  
Wife argues that 
  under the Guidelines, she is entitled to $1,605.00 in child support per month.Â  
  The family court was not required to follow the Guidelines in this case.Â  In 
  cases where the parentsâ€™ combined income exceeds the highest amount contemplated 
  by the Guidelines, courts are to decide the issue of amount on a case-by-case 
  basis. [7] Â  27 S.C. Code Ann. 
  Reg. 114- 4710(A)(3) (Supp. 2003).Â  We find no abuse of discretion in the family 
  courtâ€™s child support award.
Additionally, 
  Wife argues the trial judge erred in ordering that both parties share equally 
  in transportation expenses to effect the visitation order.Â  We hold that under 
  the circumstances of this case, and considering Husbandâ€™s unilateral action 
  in moving to California, Husband should bear the transportation expenses for 
  older son to travel to South Carolina and the two younger children to travel 
  to California to effect the visitation schedule set forth by the family courtâ€™s 
  order dated January 2, 2003 and filed January 6, 2003.
V.Â  Attorneyâ€™s 
  Fees and Litigation Expenses
Wife 
  argues the trial court erroneously failed to award her reasonable attorneyâ€™s 
  fees and litigation expenses.Â Â  We disagree. 
Pursuant to South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-420(38) (Supp. 2003), 
  attorneyâ€™s fees may be assessed against a party in an action brought in the 
  family court.Â  An award of attorneyâ€™s fees rests within the sound discretion 
  of the trial judge and should not be disturbed on appeal unless there is an 
  abuse of discretion.Â  Ariail v. Ariail, 295 S.C. 486, 369 S.E.2d 146 
  (Ct. App. 1997).
Wifeâ€™s counsel agreed to represent her in the remand trial for a 
  flat fee of $35,000.00.Â  The flat fee did not include costs such as depositions, 
  Guardian ad Litem fees, and other expenses.Â  The flat fee of $35,000.00 plus 
  other expenses totals more than $90,000.00.
The family court concluded that â€œeach party is well able to pay reasonable 
  attorneyâ€™s fees to their respective attorneyâ€ and each party should pay their 
  own attorneyâ€™s fees because each was â€œentirely unreasonable with respect to 
  part of the remand issues.â€Â Â  The family court went on to note that Husband 
  has substantially greater wealth than Wife, but Wife â€œappears to have paid her 
  fees prior to the trial and the fees will not affect the standard of living 
  of either party.â€Â  
In determining whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should 
  consider each partyâ€™s ability to pay his or her own fee; the beneficial results 
  obtained by the attorney; the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions; and 
  the effect of the fee on each partyâ€™s standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M, 
  307 S.C. 471, 415 S.E.2d 812 (1992).Â  The only factor weighing in favor of Wife 
  is the beneficial results achieved by her attorney.Â  The trial judge found that 
  Wife could pay her attorneyâ€™s fees and that it would not affect her standard 
  of living.Â  The family court judge did not abuse his discretion.Â  Wife has not 
  shown she is unable to pay her attorneyâ€™s fees and by all accounts has, in fact, 
  paid the $35,000 portion of her fee.Â  See R.G.M. v. D.E.M., 306 
  S.C. 145, 410 S.E.2d 564 (1991) (denying wifeâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees 
  where the wife provided no reasons for not being able to pay fees).
The same considerations that apply to awarding attorneyâ€™s fees apply 
  to awarding litigation expenses.Â  Nienow v. Nienow, 268 S.C. 161, 173, 
  232 S.E.2d 504, 510 (1977).Â  Wife has a stronger case for litigation expenses 
  than attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Wife argues she paid $6,000.00 for her California attorneys, 
  $811.38 for the two depositions, and $1,962.00 for Husbandâ€™s CPA in California.Â  
  Wife would not have incurred these expenses had Husband not moved to California.Â  
  The Court has awarded litigation expenses in other cases, where one party has 
  incurred expenses as a result of the unilateral action of another.Â  See 
  e.g., Stevenson v. Stevenson, 295 S.C. 412, 368 S.E.2d 901 (1988) 
  (reimbursable expenses include the reasonable and necessary expenses incurred 
  in obtaining evidence of spouseâ€™s infidelity).Â  We order Husband to pay Wife 
  $8,773.38 in litigation expenses.Â  
CONCLUSION
For 
  the foregoing reasons we affirm as modified the decision of the family court.Â  
  We conclude (1) the family court judge did not abuse his discretion in failing 
  to recuse himself; (2) the family court did not abuse its discretion in awarding 
  custody of the two younger children to Wife; (3) Wife is entitled to $1,500.00 
  per month in permanent periodic alimony and $91,500.00 in retroactive alimony 
  plus interest at a rate of fourteen percent per annum; (4) Husband is to pay 
  Wife $1,150.00 per month in child support and transportation expenses needed 
  to effect the family courtâ€™s visitation schedule; and (5) Wife is responsible 
  for her own attorneyâ€™s fees, but is owed $8,773.38 in litigation expenses by 
  Husband.
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED. 
MOORE, A.C.J., WALLER, 
  PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice John W. Kittredge, concur.

    The trial date had originally been set for May 6, 2002, but had been postponed.Â  
    In April 2002, both parties requested a continuance, which was granted, in 
    part, to allow time for discovery to be conducted in California.

 
   [2] The letters were respectively 
    dated August 23, 2002, August 30, 2002, and September 3, 2002.

 
  Â [3] Husband characterizes younger 
    sonâ€™s preference as one for the â€œFather.â€Â  The Guardian ad Litem testified 
    younger son liked â€œCalifornia a little bit more now, that he likes his school, 
    had friends, and was doing well.â€Â  We conclude that although younger son expressed 
    some positive opinions about living in California, he did not necessarily 
    attribute this to living with Husband as opposed to Wife.

    (1) the duration of the marriage together with the ages of the parties at

  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(C) (Supp. 2003)

    by multiplying the original $2,500.00 pendente lite award by the sixty-one

    (Supp. 2003) provides all money decrees shall draw interest at a rate of twelve 
    percent per year.Â  However, this statute was amended, effective January 1, 
    2001.Â  Therefore, the twelve percent interest rate only applies to causes 
    of action arising or accruing on or after January 1, 2001.Â  2000 S.C. Act 
    No. 344, Â§ 4.Â  Because this action arose prior to January 1, 2001, the applicable

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Anand B. Patel,       
Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Nalini Raja Patel,       
Â Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Dillon County
James A. Spruill, III, Family Court 
  Judge

Opinion No. 25825
Heard February 19, 2004 - Filed May 
  24, 2004

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
J. Leeds Barroll, IV, of Columbia, and John O. McDougall, of McDougall & 
  Self, P.A., of Columbia, for Appellant.
J. Michael Taylor and Harvey L. Golden, both of Golden, Taylor, Potterfield 
  & Barron, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


 ACTING JUSTICE MACAULAY:Â  
  The issue before us is whether the family court erred in denying Anand B. 
  Patel post-judgment interest on funds in a brokerage account, which the family 
  court had previously ordered escrowed pending appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Anand B. Patel (â€œHusbandâ€) and 
  Nalini Patel (â€œWifeâ€) were married on July 7, 1980.Â Â  The final decree of divorce 
  dated October 23, 1997, and filed November 12, 1997 awarded Husband 65 percent 
  of the marital estate and Wife 35 percent.Â  The marital estate included funds 
  in an A.G. Edwards brokerage account (the â€œaccountâ€).Â  The funds in the account 
  were generated primarily from the sale of the partiesâ€™ Holiday Inn and lot in 
  San Diego, California.Â  Husbandâ€™s attorney transferred these funds to an account 
  pursuant to an order issued by the family court appointing him trustee for the 
  parties and ordering him to place the funds in an interest bearing account.Â  

 On November 14, 1997, Husband, 
  who still maintained control of the account, withdrew the entire balance of 
  the account amounting to $1,870,143.63.Â  Husband used some of the funds to pay 
  taxes, leaving the remainder for disbursement between Husband and Wife.Â  Husband 
  issued Wife a check for $659,744.00. 
  [1] Â  Wife returned the check to Husbandâ€™s counsel to be reinvested in the 
  account.
On December 15, 1997, Wife filed 
  a motion requesting that Husband be required to re-deposit all funds withdrawn 
  from the account.Â  On January 12, 1998, the family court issued an order directing 
  Husband to restore $1,093,070.00 to the account, or other similar trust account, 
  bearing the best possible interest rate. [2] Â  The court ordered that these funds remain 
  in the account until conclusion of the appeal.
On November 19, 2001, Husband 
  and Wife executed an agreement to disburse the funds in the account.Â  However, 
  the parties disagreed on whether Husband was entitled to post-judgment interest 
  on the account and explicitly left this issue unresolved.Â  In their agreement, 
  the parties calculated their respective shares of the account based on the percentages 
  allocated in the final divorce decree.Â  The divorce decree awarded $701,655.00 
  from the account to Wife, with the balance to Husband.Â  The $701,665.00 constituted 
  64.19 percent of the account, leaving 35.81 percent of the account for Husband. [3] Â  The parties agreed Wife would 
  receive $791,840.41, which amounted to 64.19 percent of the balance of the account 
  on the date of the agreement.Â  However, the parties agreed to subtract $150,000 
  from Wifeâ€™s disbursement to remain in the account pending resolution of the 
  partiesâ€™ dispute over Husbandâ€™s entitlement to post-judgment interest.Â  Pursuant 
  to the agreement, Husband received his full 35.81 percent.
On May 17, 2002, Wife filed a 
  motion alleging Husband failed to communicate with her about resolving his post-judgment 
  interest claim on the 35.81 percent of the account he was awarded under the 
  partiesâ€™ agreement.Â  Wife requested the court award her the $150,000 plus accrued 
  interest, which had been withheld from her portion of the funds.Â  The court 
  awarded the $150,000 plus accrued interest held in escrow to Wife.
ISSUE

Did the family court err in denying Husbandâ€™s claim 
  for post-judgment interest and awarding Wife the $150,000 plus accrued interest 
  remaining in the A.G. Edwards account?

ANALYSIS
On appeal, Husband argues 
  he is entitled to $142,447.00 minus the interest on the $41,000 in attorneyâ€™s 
  fees originally assessed against Wife. [4] Â  We disagree.
In Casey v. Casey, 311 
  S.C. 243, 428 S.E.2d 714 (1993), we held that fixed awards of money for equitable 
  distribution do, in fact, accrue interest at the post-judgment rate from the 
  date of the judgment.Â  However, we qualified our holding stating,

We leave intact the family courtâ€™s broad discretion 
  to provide for the payment of interest as part of 
  the equitable distribution award.Â  Thus, the family court may 
  provide for the amortization of payments 
  with a rate of interest different from the post-judgment rate or deny interest 
  altogether on payment due at a future date. 

Id. at 716.Â  Our decision in Casey 
  is controlling.Â  The family courtâ€™s January 12, 1998 order specifically provided 
  that the $1,093,070.00, which the family court ordered to remain in the account 
  or other similar trust account, was to bear the â€œbest possible interest rate.â€Â  
  In designating the controlling interest rate, the family court exercised its 
  discretion in providing for an interest rate other than the post-judgment interest 
  rate.Â  Therefore, Husband is not entitled to post-judgment interest on his share 
  of funds in the account.Â  Accordingly, we hold that the family court did not 
  err in awarding Wife the remaining $150,000 plus accrued interest. 
Husband argues that the divorce 
  decree dated October 23, 1997, was silent as to the rate of interest to be applied 
  to the equitable division award, rendering the post-judgment rate applicable.Â  
  According to Husband, the post-judgment rate applies because Wife failed to 
  appeal within thirty days of the final divorce decree. 
In appeals from 
  the family court, a notice of appeal must be served on respondents within thirty 
  days after receipt of written notice of entry of the order or judgment.Â  Rule 
  203(b)(3), SCACR.Â  However, when a timely motion pursuant to Rule 59, SCRCP, 
  has been made, the time for appeal for all parties is stayed and runs from receipt 
  of written notice of entry of the order granting or denying the motion.Â  Rule 
  203(b)(1), SCACR.  
Wife filed two 
  timely Rule 59(e) motions raising the issue of whether at least part of the 
  marital funds divided between the parties should be placed in escrow pending 
  appeal.Â  Wife subsequently filed a more specific motion requesting an emergency 
  hearing due to fears Husband might leave the jurisdiction and dispose of marital 
  funds.Â  The emergency hearing was held and resulted in the January 12, 1998 
  order directing Husband to return funds to the brokerage account.Â  The January 
  12 order was reiterated in the June 4, 1998 order disposing of both of Wifeâ€™s 
  motions to reconsider.Â  Subsequently, Wife timely filed her notice of appeal.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons we 
  affirm the holding of the family court and order the remaining $150,000 plus 
  accrued interest in the A.G. Edwards account be disbursed to Wife.
AFFIRMED.

  and Acting Justice John W. Kittredge, concur.

    $701,665.00 from this account.Â  Husband deducted $41,920.94 for attorneyâ€™s 
    fees and costs the family court ordered Wife to pay under the Final Divorce 
    Decree.Â  The attorneyâ€™s fee award was later reversed by the Court of Appeals.Â  
    Patel v. Patel, Op. No. 2000-UP-653 (S.C. Ct. App. dated Oct. 26, 2000).Â  
    We affirmed. 

 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  [2] The final order to disburse funds 
    indicates $1,093,070.00 was the specified amount because that amount was needed 
    to protect Wifeâ€™s interest.

 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  [3] Wifeâ€™s 35 percent of the marital 
    estate includes 64.19 percent of the account. 

 
  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  [4] Husband adopts the family courtâ€™s 
    computation.Â  In its order to disburse funds, the court considers how much 
    Husband would be entitled to at a 14 percent post judgment interest rate assuming 
    he is entitled to such an award.Â  The court concluded, at most, Husband would 
    be entitled to $142,447.00 in accrued interest on $391,405.00.Â Â  The court 
    reasoned that of the $1,093,070.00 ordered to be held in escrow, $701,665.00 
    of those funds were Wifeâ€™s according to the divorce decree, leaving only $391,405.00 
    of Husbandâ€™s money in the account.Â  The court also noted the $142,447.00 did 
    not include the offset Wife would be entitled to receive for judgment interest 
    on the approximately $41,000.00 in attorneys fees originally assessed against 
    her and which was reversed on appeal.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In the Supreme Court


  
    
      
Lewis C.
Patterson,        Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
State of South
Carolina,        Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal From Greenwood County
Gary E. Clary, Trial Judge
Wyatt T. Saunders, Post-Conviction Judge

Opinion No. 25826
Submitted April 21, 2004 - Filed May 
  24, 2004

REVERSED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney 
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, 
  Assistant Attorney General Adrianne L. Turner, all of Columbia, for petitioner.
Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for respondent. 
      
    
  

JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Respondent Lewis Clarence Patterson 
  (Patterson) pled guilty to possession of crack cocaine, second offense, and 
  was sentenced to seven (7) years imprisonment and fined $10,000.Â  Patterson 
  was previously convicted of possession of marihuana.Â  Concluding trial counsel 
  rendered ineffective assistance of counsel by advising Patterson to plead guilty 
  to a second offense in connection with the crack cocaine charge, the post-conviction 
  (PCR) judge granted relief. 
ISSUE
Did the PCR judge err in holding Pattersonâ€™s counsel was 
  ineffective because Patterson was sentenced as a second-time offender?
ANALYSIS
 The State argues the PCR judge erred by concluding Pattersonâ€™s 
  counsel was ineffective in advising him to plead guilty where Pattersonâ€™s sentence 
  for possession of crack cocaine was enhanced to second offense due to Pattersonâ€™s 
  1989 conviction for possession of marihuana.Â  We agree.
To establish a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel, 
  the PCR applicant must establish that trial counselâ€™s representation fell below 
  an objective standard of reasonableness and that, but for counselâ€™s errors, 
  there is a reasonable probability the result would have been different.Â  Strickland 
  v. Washington, 466 U.S. 668, 104 S.Ct. 2052, 80 L.Ed.2d 674 (1984).Â Â  â€œA 
  reasonable probability is a probability sufficient to undermine confidence in 
  the outcomeâ€ of trial.Â  Id. 466 U.S. at 694, 104 S.Ct. at 2068, 80 L.Ed.2d 
  at 698.Â  The PCR judgeâ€™s findings will be upheld by this Court when they are 
  supported by any evidence of probative value.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 
  115, 386 S.E.2d 624 (1989).Â  However, the Court will not uphold the findings 
  of the PCR court if no probative evidence supports those findings.Â  Holland 
  v. State, 322 S.C. 111, 470 S.E.2d 378 (1996).
There is no statutory law or judicial 
  precedent in this State concluding, under similar facts, the trial judge improperly 
  enhanced Pattersonâ€™s sentence.Â  An attorney is not required to anticipate potential 
  changes in the law, which are not in existence at the time of the conviction.Â  
  State v. Gilmore, 314 S.C. 453, 457, 445 S.E.2d 454, 456 (1994) overruled 
  on other grounds by Brightman v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 520 S.E.2d 
  614 (1999).Â  Therefore, Pattersonâ€™s counsel was not deficient in advising Patterson 
  to plead guilty in connection with the crack cocaine charge.
Although, unnecessary for resolution of 
  Pattersonâ€™s claim, we address whether Patterson was incorrectly sentenced as 
  a second- time offender.Â  Patterson was sentenced pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. 
Â§ 44-53-375(A) (2002), which provides: 


For a second offense, the offender is 
  guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, must be imprisoned not more than ten yearsâ€¦. 
  For a third or subsequent offense, the offender is guilty of a felony and, upon conviction, must be imprisoned 
  not less than ten years nor more than fifteen yearsâ€¦.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375(A) (2002).
Section 44-53-375(A) does not define 
  second offense.Â  South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-470 (2002), generally defines 
  â€œsecond or subsequent offenseâ€ as when an offender â€œhas at any time been convicted 
  under this article or under any State or Federal statute relating to narcotic 
  drugs, marihuana, depressant, stimulant, or hallucinogenic drugs.â€Â  
Under Section 44-53-470, a prior offense is any 
  drug offense, including possession of marihuana.Â  Sections 44-53-375(A) and 
  44-53-470 are part of the same general law and can be read together without 
  conflict.Â  Cf. In re Keith Lamont G., 304 S.C. 456, 405 S.E.2d 
  404 (1991) (statutory sections that are part of the same general statutory law 
  must be construed together).Â  Moreover, all rules of statutory construction 
  are secondary to the rule that legislative intent must prevail if it can be 
  reasonably discerned from the statutory language.Â Â  Samuels v. State, 
  356 S.C. 635, 591 S.E.2d 606 (2004).Â  The legislature could not have intended 
  to exclude marihuana possession as a second or subsequent offense under Section 
  44-53-375(A) when Section 44-53-470 specifically defines a â€œsecond or subsequent 
  offenseâ€ as any drug offense, including marihuana.Â  When the terms of a statute 
  are clear, the court must apply those terms according to their literal meaning.Â  
  Holley v. Mount Vernon Mills, Inc., 312 S.C. 320, 440 S.E.2d 373 (1994).Â  
  Therefore, Pattersonâ€™s sentence was properly enhanced based on his prior conviction 
  for marihuana.
The PCR judge relied on Rainey v. 
  State, 307 S.C. 150, 414 S.E.2d 131 (1992).Â  Rainey is inapposite 
  to the case at bar.Â  Rainey pled guilty to distribution of crack cocaine and 
  was sentenced as a second offender under former Section 44-53-375 because of 
  prior convictions for marihuana possession.Â Â  Under former Section 44-53-375(B) 
  (Supp. 1990), the prior offense was limited to narcotic drugs.Â  The Court explained:

[Rainey] was sentenced as a second offender under the crack 
  cocaine statute [S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-375 (Supp. 1990)] based on his prior convictions for marijuana and
possession with intent to distribute marijuana.Â  Pursuant 
  to Â§ 44-53-375(B), an enhanced sentence is required for a â€œsecond 
  offender, or if, in the case of a first conviction of a violation of this section, 
  the offender has been convicted of any [law] â€¦ relating to narcotic drugsâ€¦â€ 
  (Emphasis added).Â  Since [Rainey] does not have a prior crack cocaine conviction 
  and marijuana is not a narcotic drug as defined by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-110 
  (1985), he should not have been sentenced as a second offender under Â§ 44-53-375(B).

Rainey, 307 S.C. at 151, 414 S.E.2d at 132 (footnote 
  omitted).Â  The State argued Rainey was a second offender under Section 44-53-470.Â  
  In affirming the order of the PCR judge, the Court concluded:

Because there is a conflict between Â§ 44-53-375(B) and the 
  general second offense statute, the later, more specific crack cocaine statute 
  must prevail.Â  The PCR judge was correct in finding that [Rainey] is not a second 
  offender under Â§ 44-53-375(B) and should not, therefore, have been sentenced 
  as one.

Rainey, 307 S.C. at 152, 414 S.E.2d at 132.
Here, Sections 44-53-375(A) and 44-53-470 
  are not in conflict.Â  See also Thomas v. State, 319 S.C. 
  471, 465 S.E.2d 350 (1995) (finding no conflict between Sections 44-53-370(e)(1) 
  (Supp. 1994) and 44-53-470 (1985) for purposes of sentence enhancement); State 
  v. Dupree, 354 S.C. 676, 583 S.E.2d 437 (Ct. App. 2003) (finding no conflict 
  between Sections 44-53-375(C)(1)(b) (2002) and 44-53-470 (2002) for purposes 
  of sentence enhancement).Â  
 REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
